awd_titl_txt: RUI: Characterization of Reactive Transients in Heterogeneous Atmospheric Photochemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Ephraim Woods of Colgate University to study short-lived chemical species that are generated by the interaction of light with aerosol particles which are similar to those found in the troposphere. One goal of the work is to determine the conditions that promote the growth of organic aerosol particles through photochemistry.  These secondary organic aerosol particles influence climate through their effects on the Earth's radiation balance.  In terms of broader scientific impact, this research is expected to lead to a better understanding of the processes that affect climate and help scientists to forge improved predictive models.  Another impact is the professional development of the undergraduates at Colgate University who conduct this work.  In participating as team members on this project, undergraduates gain experience in research methods and become better prepared for graduate work in the sciences.

Experiments in this project are designed to examine photochemically generated transient species in aerosol systems using photoionization methods. One type of experiment will probe the formation of secondary organic aerosols (SOA) through the reactive uptake of volatile organic molecules (VOCs) with particle phase triplet photosensitizers. The goal of this work is to further understand how the structure and morphology of the air-particle interface influences the kinetics of this newly identified SOA formation mechanism. Another type of experiment investigates the production of radicals from nitrate-containing particles.  A third experiment characterizes solvated electrons in environments that are unexplored and not accessible through other experiments.  The investigation of aerosol properties and surfaces in these studies is expected to establish an improved molecular-level understanding of these complex chemical systems.

por.por_cntn:
We developed a new experimental technique for understanding how sunlight can drive chemical reactions in atmospheric aerosol particles. Aerosol particles play an important role in determining the balance of energy coming in from the sun and energy that the earth radiates back out to space. The composition of aerosol particles is an important variable in understanding their overall effect. Some of the chemistry that alters the composition of aerosol particles in the atmosphere is initiated by sunlight, and this photochemistry usually involves the creation of highly-reactive and short-lived chemical species. We developed an method that is fast enough to detect these species before they react away and to measure how long they live. The rate at which they decay and how that rate depends on the conditions reveals details about the chemical mechanism of these important reactions. The technique we developed is called Time-resolved Photoelectric Activity of Aerosol, or TPEAA. In the experiment, one laser pulse plays the role of sunlight and creates the short-lived species, then another laser pulse ejects electrons from the aerosol particle, a process called photoelectric charging. Because the electrons are most easily removed from the reactive species, the amount photoelectric charging is correlated to the amount of that species. We can then “watch” these short-lived molecules decay away by seeing the charging signal decrease as we change the delay between the laser that creates them and the one that detects them.

 

In one example of the application of our method, we studied a reaction which initiates the growth of secondary organic aerosol particles. Secondary organic aerosol (SOA) are aerosol particles that incorporate gaseous compounds, such as the biogenic emission from plants, into aerosol particles as the result of chemical processes. Some of the SOA-making reactions depend on the creation of energized molecules through the absorption of sunlight. These photosensitizer molecules initiate a chain reaction that leads to uptake of gaseous organic compounds from the air into existing aerosol particles. We found that the fate of the energized photosensitizer depends on the chemical environment near the surface of the aerosol particles. That observation is important, because real aerosol particles in the atmosphere are more complex in composition and morphology than the idealized versions accessible to other methods of analysis. We have also applied our new technique to the study of the effects of ionizing radiation on the chemistry of atmospheric aerosol particles. The ionization of species in aerosol particle that contain liquid water can result in the formation of hydrated electrons. Our experiment measures the lifetimes of these hydrated electrons for the first time in realistic models for atmospheric aerosol particles.

 

All the work on this project was accomplished by undergraduate researchers at Colgate University, many of whom have gone on to graduate studies in chemistry and related fields. Some students participated in a summer outreach program where they were able to engage visiting high school students in the process of data collection and analysis for ambient aerosol particles.
